newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - Regionals slip on dollar strength.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Regionals slip on dollar strength.

text.p: * Most regional currencies lower on dollar's renewed surge against majors and dollar short-covering ahead of holiday period.
* Indonesian rupiah relatively steady as market focuses on liquidity conditions.
* Thai baht hit by dollar strength and weak sentiment for local currency, which spurs continued buying of forwards.
* Malaysian ringgit easier, tracking dollar/majors but downside limited by demand from Japanese and U.S. funds.
* Singapore dollar weak and sluggish after overnight fall.
Short-covering of the U.S. dollar ahead of the Chinese and Moslem New Year holidays dominated activity in most Asian regional currency markets, dealers said on Wednesday.
The dollar's renewed surge to a four-year high of 122.85 yen in early Tokyo trade reinforced the trend. It was quoted at 122.70/80 at o445 GMT.
Only the Indonesian rupiah held relatively steady amid bearish sentiment for the dollar and concerns about money market liquidity.
Dealers in Jakarta said operators were kept from pushing the dollar lower by the central bank's floor rate, but sentiment remained weak for the U.S. unit.
"This is due to the ongoing moves by players to establish short dollar positions to catch weekend premiums when they cover back on Thursday or Friday," said a local bank dealer.
"The premiums for five days are not bad," he added.
The foreign exchange market will be closed for Eid al-Fitr on February 10 and 11 and reopen on February 12, while the stock market will be closed from February 7 to 11 inclusive.
Spot rupiah was quoted at 2,373.50/74.50 at 0445 GMT, compared with an opening of 2,373.5/74.5.
Dealers said interbank rates were relatively volatile due to fluctuating short-term swap rates. They said people in the region were already in a holiday mood.
The local bank dealer said offshore players seemed to expect a possible rupiah injection from the central bank if the dollar fell out of its band again, thus driving swap rates down.
In Thailand, the baht slid to 25.935-25.945 to the dollar at 0445 GMT against 25.890/25.895 late on Tuesday. The Bank of Thailand fixed the baht/dollar mid-rate at 25.89 against 25.86 on Tuesday.
"Dollar's bullish mood abroad triggered a new round of buying of the currency here. Most market players took long dollar positions," said a dealer at a foreign bank in Bangkok.

"There's a lot of buying interest in the spot and forwards out of Tokyo. People are just trying to square out all their carry-trade positions ahead of the New Year holidays," said a U.S. bank dealer in Singapore.
He said news of a proposed cut of 59 billion baht in government spending did not boost sentiment for Thailand.
"I think the market is still very uncomfortable with being short dollars against the baht," he said.
But Bangkok dealers said dollar buying was restrained by tight baht liquidity in the local money market.
The overnight interbank rate rose to 14.50-15.00 percent in early trade from 13.00-14.00 late on Tuesday on heavy demand for funds for the Lunar New Year and for bank reserve requirements.
The Malaysian ringgit was easier as players squared their positions ahead of the holidays, dealers said.
"The market is a bit on neutral ground, but there is more squaring today because tomorrow everybody will go on long holidays," said a dealer with a European bank in Singapore.
He said the market was still short dollars, but any retreat of the ringgit would be capped at 2.50, where the Malaysian unit had support from Japanese and select U.S. funds.
Malaysian banks are closed from Friday through Tuesday for the Lunar New Year and Moslem Eid al-Fitr festivals.
Further south, the Singapore dollar was also dented by the U.S. unit's bullish stance, but dealers said activity remained very slow.

"Yesterday, people started buying the dollar/Sing because they can earn a little bit more on swap points due to the interest rate play, but there's commercial selling interest at 1.4110," said the U.S. bank dealer.
"The overnight high was at 1.4099/1.4100 so we're not breaking any new ground today," he added.
-- Madhav Reddy in Kuala Lumpur (603-230 8911), Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (62-21-384-6364), Anuchit Nguyen in Bangkok (662) 652-0642 and Sonali Desai in Singapore (65-8703090)
